columns.text: The sensitivity of the OCF refers to how it is affected by the change in quantity sold.

In order to solve for OCF, we need to use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}&=[(\text{P}-\text{v})\times \text{Q}-\text{FC}] \times (1-\text{T})+(\text{T}\times \text{D})
\end{aligned}$$

where,

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{P}&=\text{Price per unit}\\
\text{v}&=\text{variable cost per unit}\\
\text{Q}&=\text{Quantity}\\
\text{FC}&=\text{Fixed cost}\\
\text{T}&=\text{Tax rate}\\
\text{D}&=\text{Depreciation}
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation is obtained by simply dividing the initial investment over the time

Substituting the given values, we will be able to get the initial OCF:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{OCF}_{\text{old}}&=[(\$29-\$19)\times 76,000-\$235,000]\\
&\times(1-0.21)+(.21 \times \$143,750)\\[15 pt]
&=\$525,000\times0.79+\$30,187.50\\[15 pt]
&=\$444,937.50
\end{aligned}$$

Since we are studying the sensitivity of OCF to the change in quantity, we can then input a different value for the quantity while keeping the other variables the same. In this case, we will use $\text{Q}=80,000$

Plugging in the values to the equation in the first step, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\dfrac{\$476,537.50 - \$444,937.50}{80,000 - 76,000}&=\$7.90
\end{aligned}$$

This means that for every additional unit sold, the OCF is increased by $\$7.90$
